On local invariants of pure three-qubit states



Anthony Sudbery

Department of Mathematics
University of York
Heslington
York
England YO1 5DD
Email: as2@york.ac.uk

24 February 2000, revised 15 November 2000
Abstract

We study invariants of three-qubit states under local unitary transformations, i.e. functions on the space of entanglement types, which is known to have dimension 6. We show that there is no set of six algebraically independent polynomial invariants of degree ≤6absent6RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:6\leq 6, and find such a set with maximum degree 8. We describe an intrinsic definition of a canonical state on each orbit, and discuss the (non-polynomial) invariants associated with it.

1 Introduction

The invariants of many-particle states under unitary transformations which act on single particles separately (“local” transformations) are of interest [3, 7, 9, 10, 12] because they give the finest discrimination between different types of entanglement. They can be regarded as coordinates on the space of entanglement types (equivalently, the space of orbits of the group of local transformations). In this paper we study the case of pure states of three spin-1212FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end\tfrac{1}{2} particles, or qubits. For mixed states of two qubits, it is possible to give a complete set of invariants [11], describing the 9-dimensional space of orbits in terms of 18 invariants, nine of which may be taken to have only discrete values (for example, the signs of certain polynomials listed in [11]). For pure three-qubit states, where the space of orbits is known [3] to be 6-dimensional, we can at present do no more than find a set of six algebraically independent invariants. We will show (Section 3) that in order to do this with polynomials in the state coordinates it is necessary to go to polynomials of order 8, and we will exhibit (Section 4) a set of six independent invariants; their physical meaning is discussed in Section 5. We will also discuss (Section 6) the possibility of finding a more convenient set of non-polynomial invariants. Section 2 is an introductory discussion of the invariants of pure n𝑛italic-nn-qubit states.

2 Pure states: general considerations

A general theory of local invariants of mixed n𝑛italic-nn-particle states has been given by Rains and Grassl et al. [7, 12]. Here we review the part of that theory that refers to pure states.

3 Polynomial invariants of three-qubit states

For the remainder of the paper we consider three spin-1212FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end\tfrac{1}{2} particles A,B,C𝐴𝐵𝐶italic-A PUNCT:, italic-B PUNCT:, italic-CA,B,C. The classification of pure states of this system has been discussed in [4, 14], and their invariants in [5, 8]. It is known [9] that the dimension of the space of orbits is 6; there are therefore six algebraically independent local invariants. We will show that there are no more than five algebraically independent invariants of degree less than 8, and exhibit a set of six algebraically independent invariants with maximum degree 8.111I understand that similar conclusions have been reached by Markus Grassl [6].

The vector space of homogeneous invariants of degree 2⁢r2𝑟NUMBER:2 italic-r2r is spanned by functions Pσ⁢τsubscript𝑃𝜎𝜏italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-sigma italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:endP_{\sigma\tau} labelled by pairs of elements of Srsubscript𝑆𝑟italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:endS_{r}, the group of permutations of r𝑟italic-rr things. Thus there is one independent invariant of degree 2,

4 Physical significance of the invariants

The invariant I1subscript𝐼1italic-I POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endI_{1} is just the norm of the three-party state and therefore has no physical significance; we will normally set it equal to 1. The three invariants I1,I2,I3subscript𝐼1subscript𝐼2subscript𝐼3italic-I POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-I POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-I POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endI_{1},I_{2},I_{3} are one-particle quantities, giving the eigenvalues of the one-particle density matrices; they are equivalent to the one-particle entropies, which measure how entangled each particle is with the other two together. The entanglement in each pair of particles and the three-way entanglement of the whole system are all given by the last invariant I6subscript𝐼6italic-I POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endI_{6}, as follows. A good measure of the entanglement of two qubits A,B𝐴𝐵italic-A PUNCT:, italic-BA,B in a mixed state is the 2-tangle τA⁢Bsubscript𝜏𝐴𝐵italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\tau_{AB} [5], which is a monotonic function of the entanglement of formation [16]. The three-way entanglement of three qubits A,B,C𝐴𝐵𝐶italic-A PUNCT:, italic-B PUNCT:, italic-CA,B,C in a pure state is measured by the 3-tangle

The remaining invariant, I5subscript𝐼5italic-I POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endI_{5}, is a different and independent measure of the entanglement of each pair of qubits. Its existence shows that the 2-tangles and 3-tangle are not sufficient to determine a pure 3-qubit state up to local equivalence. 5 Canonical coordinates

An alternative type of invariant, not necessarily a polynomial in the coordinates of the state vector, is obtained by specifying a canonical point on each orbit. The values of the invariant functions at any point are then the coordinates of the canonical point on its orbit. The canonical points lie on a manifold corresponding to the space of orbits, and their coordinates can (at least locally) be expressed in terms of an appropriate number of parameters.

One form of canonical state was suggested independently by Linden and Popescu [9] and by Schlienz [13], who pointed out that any pure state of three qubits can be written as
